question.title: How Does JVM Store Data to ByteBuffer?

node.contents: It is a `BYTE` buffer. and range of byte is `-128 to 127`. So it cannot represent `129` and will overflow to `-127`.

astNode.text: It is a `BYTE` buffer. and range of byte is `-128 to 127`. So it cannot represent `129` and will overflow to `-127`.

node.contents: P.S. they JVM doesn't convert anything, these are just the byte values of those types.

astNode.text: P.S. they JVM doesn't convert anything, these are just the byte values of those types.

node.contents: I just learned about Java's ByteBuffer, I am a little confused with how JVM storing multiple data types into a ByteBuffer. This is the codes:

astNode.text: I just learned about Java's ByteBuffer, I am a little confused with how JVM storing multiple data types into a ByteBuffer. This is the codes:

elements.contents: public static void main(String[] args) { ByteBuffer BF1 = ByteBuffer.allocate(30); BF1.putChar('A'); BF1.putChar('B'); BF1.putInt(129); BF1.putDouble(0.98); BF1.putFloat(8.9f); byte[] BA1 = new byte[BF1.position()]; BF1.position(0); BF1.get(BA1, 0, BA1.length); System.out.print("BA1 ="); for(byte a: BA1) System.out.print(" " + a); } /*output BA1 = 0 65 0 66 0 0 0 -127 63 -17 92 40 -11 -62 -113 92 65 14 102 102 **/

units.rawText: public static void main(String[] args) { ByteBuffer BF1 = ByteBuffer.allocate(30); BF1.putChar('A'); BF1.putChar('B'); BF1.putInt(129); BF1.putDouble(0.98); BF1.putFloat(8.9f); byte[] BA1 = new byte[BF1.position()]; BF1.position(0); BF1.get(BA1, 0, BA1.length); System.out.print("BA1 ="); for(byte a: BA1) System.out.print(" "+ a); } /*output BA1 = 0 65 0 66 0 0 0 -127 63 -17 92 40 -11 -62 -113 92 65 14 102 102 **/

node.contents: How JVM convert int 129 to be 0 0 0 -127, why is it not written as 0 0 0 129? Then how JVM convert Float and Double types in ByteBuffer like result above?

node.contents: The simplest approach is to read the code. For example to write/read a long it calls

astNode.text: The simplest approach is to read the code. For example to write/read a long it calls

elements.contents: static void putLongB(ByteBuffer bb, int bi, long x) { bb._put(bi + 0, long7(x)); bb._put(bi + 1, long6(x)); bb._put(bi + 2, long5(x)); bb._put(bi + 3, long4(x)); bb._put(bi + 4, long3(x)); bb._put(bi + 5, long2(x)); bb._put(bi + 6, long1(x)); bb._put(bi + 7, long0(x)); }

units.rawText: static void putLongB(ByteBuffer bb, int bi, long x) { bb._put(bi + 0, long7(x)); bb._put(bi + 1, long6(x)); bb._put(bi + 2, long5(x)); bb._put(bi + 3, long4(x)); bb._put(bi + 4, long3(x)); bb._put(bi + 5, long2(x)); bb._put(bi + 6, long1(x)); bb._put(bi + 7, long0(x)); }

elements.contents: static long getLongB(long a) { return makeLong(_get(a + 0), _get(a + 1), _get(a + 2), _get(a + 3), _get(a + 4), _get(a + 5), _get(a + 6), _get(a + 7)); }

units.rawText: static long getLongB(long a) { return makeLong(_get(a + 0), _get(a + 1), _get(a + 2), _get(a + 3), _get(a + 4), _get(a + 5), _get(a + 6), _get(a + 7)); }

node.contents: assuming you have the default Big Endian byte order.

astNode.text: assuming you have the default Big Endian byte order.

node.contents: If you use a direct ByteBuffer it uses the Unsafe class which is treated as an intrinsic and turned into a machine code instruction. i.e. the CPU does the work.

astNode.text: If you use a direct ByteBuffer it uses the Unsafe class which is treated as an intrinsic and turned into a machine code instruction. i.e. the CPU does the work.
